ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was an overview of Russian culture and history. I improved my ability to synthesize material, engage in meaningful discussion and think critically in section, and read lots of primary texts.
I learned to pull interesting facts from an in-depth historical overview and relate them to my specific interests.

I gained a much deeper understanding of Russian history, culture, and how the two intersected and interacted since the founding of Russia to the present, post-USSR Russia. It was also fascinating to learn about the various identity crises Russia went through and what Russian politicians, thinkers, poets, and artists had to say about those crises. I developed critical reading and discussion-leading skills through the course.
I thought I gained an understanding of Russian history and culture.
Insights into Russian culture from the 1800s to the modern-day (2000s)

You will learn the broad sweep of Russian cultural history in the modern age and develop a good overall understanding of themes, issues and trends.  It is not a course that delves into much detail, however, with one lecture devoted to each topic.  I enjoyed this wide lens though as it meant you were exposed to a number of topics and could delve deeper through the readings.
A thorough understanding of Russian history, chiefly from the time of Peter and Catherine to the present day
I developed a familiarity with modern Russian cultural history, including literature, music, art, politics, and religion.

I developed more skills with being able to critically discuss and engage with coursework with fellow students. Each discussion section was an excellent time to get to understand the course material more deeply by openly dissecting and discussing them.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: The culture classes (Prof. MacKay) were really interesting to me, and the reason why I took the course, I really looked forward to section

Weaknesses: Between 100-300 pages of reading per week which to me is a lot for an intro class, some of the history lectures were difficult for me to follow (but I also don't have any background in history or Russia)
This course is a really fascinating look at Russia. However, lectures occasionally went over dry or somewhat less interesting aspects of Russian history. Also, the readings were a bit unmanageable.

Strengths:
- Carefully chosen, varied, and interesting texts
- Lecturers had clear passion and a large knowledge base for the subject. 
- Material presented in both an engaging and informative format

Weaknesses:
- Date for the final exam/final paper was left very vague until near the end of the course, which made it hard for students to plan reading week.

Overall very good. Sometimes the lectures moved very fast and I had trouble interpreting everything being said. Sometimes I felt there was a disconnect between the "history" and the "culture" lectures.
The lectures were good but could have been better structured with more slides to make it easier to get the main points.

I think this is a wonderful course overall, but I had some minor issues with communication about the midterm and final. For one, Im not sure it was reasonable to give such a lengthy exam to be written during a 24-hour period. Another minor point was just that the communication about the date of the final exam was very late, making it difficult to plan how to study and prepare. Overall, I thought the lectures and readings were incredibly engaging.

The instructors are lovely and the lectures keep you engaged as the topic changes each week.  The readings are also well chosen and interesting.  The atmosphere of the class (even online) felt open and exploratory so I looked forward to going to class.  Sections were definitely when the discussions became more nuanced which was nice as they gave you a chance to dive deeper into ideas that had caught your attention in lecture.
Great course; good that it combines historical and cultural learning. Wouldn't change much.
This was a great course! I think the only thing that could be improved was that the time allotted for the midterm and final could be a bit longer.

I felt that the course was planned out well and did an excellent job of engaging students with course material as well as critically thinking about it and preparing it for discussing it. The topics were varied and interesting. No change is necessary.
Great readings!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There were no changes that I know of for virtual engagement other than recorded lectures. We were given 24 hours to do the midterm exam, however, the time commitment expected during that time was far more than an in-person exam.
The idea of creating slides for section was a fairly effective method for initiating discussion and reflection
Overall successful, although the lectures could have been more engaging somehow. I felt like I didn't really get to know the professors.
Having to prepare a slide for every section on the week's material was very helpful.
The discussion sections and lectures both worked well in the online format.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to people who are genuinely excited about Russian history. If they are just interested or wanting to learn more for fun, I don't think this course would be the right fit.

This is a fascinating course in some ways, but the information covered was not consistently engaging, and the workload can be difficult to manage, particularly the large reading assignments (often one book per week)
Yes; there is wonderful insight to be had into Russian culture and history, and the course offers so many avenues for further reading.
Yep, this was a cool course. I would recommend it to anyone who is interested in Russian history and culture as well. I thought the readings were super cool and the professors were very knowledgable.
Yes. If you are interested in learning more about Russia and how its present landscape reflects its history, then taking this class would be beneficial.
Yes, amazing professors and TFs. The materials and books in this class are must reads and taking this class was a great way to engage well with them.

Yes! If you want a broad understanding of Russian culture, this is definitely a class I would recommend.  I would also recommend it to a non history major who wants to explore Russian history as the lectures are easy to follow and the instructors are super helpful and open to chat in office hours about any topics that interest you.  It was a great experience and I felt I could enjoy the content of the class without the stress of a too high workload.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in Russian or European culture, history, or literature. It allows you to gain an understanding of and appreciation for the Russia's unique cultural evolution.
Yes, it is a wonderful way to get to know Russia, its people, culture, land, and history.
I would -- such an interesting set of readings.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Lecture was recorded as well, which gave students the ability to take overlapping courses
Na
We had weekly discussion sections.
Live virtual lecture that was also recorded. Live virtual discussion sections.
live virtual lecture. live virtual seminar.
I learned mostly by attending live virtual lecture but occasionally opted to watch record lecture instead. Virtual section offered some added insight.
It was a combination of live virtual lectures, recorded lectures, and virtual discussion sections.
This class was both virtual lectures coupled with virtual discussion sessions held via zoom.
